questions.text: Which of the following best describes a balanced diet?

choices.text: A diet containing micronutrients forms the bulk of the food.
A diet consisting of 70% carbohydrates, 10% proteins, and 20% fats.
A diet adhered to dietary goals focused on high protein and vitamin intake.
A diet consisting of 150 gm/day of cereals, 40 gm/day of pulses and 10 gm/day of fat.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) A diet consisting of 70% carbohydrates, 10% proteins, and 20% fats.

Explanation:

Balanced diet:

A diet containing all macro and micronutrients in required quantities to prevent any excess or deficiency.

 

Macronutrients

Micronutrients
  • Form the main bulk of the food (Option A)
  • Proportion of total energy intake (Option B):
    • Protein: 10-15%, 4 kcal/ gram
    • Carbohydrates: 50-80%, 4 kcal/gram
    • Fats: 15-30%, 9 kcal/gram
  • Required in small amounts (Option C)
  • Consists of vitamins and minerals.
  • Major minerals: Magnesium, Trace elements, Iron, Iodine, Zinc, Sodium, Potassium, Calcium.

Recommended Intake of Nutrients: (Option D)

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension visits your clinic. During the consultation, you advise the patient to adopt a diet that reduces fat and salt intake. What type of diet is being recommended to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Prudent diet

Explanation:

Prudent diet:

  • A temporary diet that adheres to dietary goals.
  • Beneficial for managing diabetes, post-op patients, cardiovascular and renal diseases.
  • Includes:
    • Fat intake: < 20-30% of total energy intake.
    • Saturated fats: < 7% of total energy intake
    • Cholesterol < 200 mg/day
    • Salt intake to <5 gm per day
    • Increase complex carbohydrates and avoid alcohol consumption.
    • Cholesterol: HDL Ratio < 3.5
    • Diet adapted for special needs: pregnancy, lactation, growth etc.

 

Most people consume a staple diet (Option A), which is culturally acceptable depending on the plants native to a region.

A high-protein diet (Option C) emphasizes higher protein intake and is often used for muscle-building or specific weight-loss plans.

Balanced diet (Option D): A diet that includes all the necessary nutrients (carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, and minerals) in the right proportions. Relevance: While generally healthy, this is too broad a term. It doesn't specifically emphasize reduced fat and salt, which is key in this case.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male reports that his diet has been low in protein. Which of the following amino acids cannot be synthesised in the body and must be obtained from the diet?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Lysine

 

Explanation:

 

Types of amino acids:

 

1. Essential AA
(Option B)
  • Not synthesised in the body, it must obtained from the diet
  • Total 9: Phenylalanine, Valine, Threonine, Tryptophan, Isoleucine, Methionine, Histidine, Phenylalanine, Lysine, Leucine.

  • (Mnemonic: PVT-TIM-HALL)

2. Non-essential AA
(Option A)
  • Synthesised in the body
  • Total 6: Arginine, Asparagine, Serine, Proline, Glycine, Glutamine

3. Conditionally-essential AA
(Option C)
  • Non-essential amino acids turn essential if precursors are limited in the body (during stress or illness)
  • Tyrosine, cysteine, glutamine

4. Semi-essential AA
(Option D)
  • Increase requirement during growth (like pregnancy)
  • Arginine, Histidine.

Match the following types of food sources with their respective limiting amino acids

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) 1:c, 2:d, 3:a, 4: b

 

Explanation:

Food item

Limiting amino acid

1. Corn/ Maize
  • Tryptophan & lysine (most common)
  • Tryptophan is a precursor of Vitamin B3 (niacin), hence its deficiency can lead to Pellagra, a condition characterized by “4 D’s” i.e., dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and in severe cases, death.

2. Cereals (Wheat, Rice)
  • Threonine & lysine
  • Rice has a slightly higher lysine content

3. Nuts
  • Lysine

4. Legumes/Pulses
  • Methionine & Cystine

 

Limiting Amino Acids: These are essential amino acids in short supply in certain foods.

  • Lysine most deficient amino acid
  • Combining vegetarian foods (e.g., rice and dal) allows proteins to complement each other, creating a complete amino acid profile.
  • Properly planned vegetarian diets with cereals, pulses, and vegetables can provide high-quality protein comparable to animal sources.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the protein efficiency ratio (PER)?

choices.text: The ratio of protein to the total energy in a diet
Measure of protein quality based on weight gain per unit of protein consumed
The balance of essential amino acids in a protein source
The proportion of protein retained for growth expressed as the amount of nitrogen absorbed.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Measure of protein quality based on weight gain per unit of protein consumed


 

Explanation:

 

Quantitative measures of protein:

 

Protein-energy ratio (Option A)

Protein Efficiency Ratio (Option B)
  • Energy from protein in food product/total energy x 100
  • PER > 2.5: Better utilisation and promotes growth (animal protein)
  • PER=0.5-2.5: supports life (vegetable protein)
  • Maximum Protein energy ratio = Fish (80%)
  • Weight gain (g) of test subject/amount of protein consumed(g) x 100
  • Laboratory indicator.
  • Assess how well the protein supports growth.

 

The balance of essential amino acids in a protein source relates to the Amino Acid Score, which measures the adequacy of essential amino acids in a protein source compared to a reference protein. (Option C)

Amino Acid Score = (mg of each essential amino acid in the test protein​ / mg of the same amino acid in the reference protein) x 100

Biological value (BV) refers to the percentage of protein retained in the body for growth, measured in terms of the amount of nitrogen absorbed. (Option D)

Biological value = (Nitrogen retained / Nitrogen absorbed) x 100

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the food's digestible amino acid content ratio to the same amino acid in a reference pattern?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Digestible Indispensable Amino Acid Score


 

Explanation:

 

Qualitative measures of protein

1.Digestible Indispensable Amino Acid Score (DIAAS)

(Option A)
  • Digestible dietary amino acid mg in 1g of dietary protein/same dietary amino acid mg in 1g of reference protein X 100
  • Ideal digestibility coefficient of a food product
  • Best indicator to measure protein quality

2. Digestibility coefficient
(Option B)
  • Amount of amino acid absorbed / amount of protein ingested.
  • External protein quality indicator of the food product.

3. Net Protein Utilization (NPU)
(Option C)


 
  • Digestibility coefficient (external indicator) x Biological value (internal indicator) / 100
  • Percentage of the ingested nitrogen retained in the body
  • 1 gm protein = 6.25gm nitrogen
  • NPU Indian diet: 50-80

4. Biological Value
  • Nitrogen retained/ Nitrogen absorbed x 100

5. Reference protein

(Option D)
  • It is the standard for measuring other proteins, such as eggs, because it has the highest NPU and contains all essential amino acids.

questions.text: Why is an egg known as a reference protein?

choices.text: It is the easiest protein to digest.
It has the highest protein content per gram.
It contains all essential amino acids.
It has the longest shelf life of all proteins.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) It contains all essential amino acids.

Explanation:


Eggs are known as reference proteins because they provide all the essential amino acids in the right proportions needed by the human body. This complete amino acid profile makes eggs a benchmark for evaluating the protein quality of other foods.

 

Egg

Importance
  • Eggs are highly nutritious and rich in protein, essential vitamins, & minerals.
  • They support muscle building, brain health, and overall wellness.

Rule of 6
  • 6 grams of protein
  • 6 grams of fat
  • 60 calories per large egg
  • 6 essential vitamins (A, B2, B12, D, E, K)
  • 60 grams average weight

Others:

  • 6x5=30 mg Calcium
  • 6x0.25=1.5mg Iron


The Net Protein Utilization (NPU) of eggs is typically around 96%. This means that 96% of the protein absorbed from eggs is retained by the body for growth and maintenance.

Eggs (Option A) are easy to digest and have high bioavailability, meaning the body can efficiently absorb and utilise the protein; this characteristic alone does not make them a reference protein.

 

Eggs are a good source of protein, but they do not have the highest protein content per gram compared to other protein-rich foods like certain types of fish or meat. (Option B)


Eggs have a reasonable shelf life when stored properly, but many other protein sources, such as dried legumes or certain preserved meats, have longer shelf lives. (Option D)

questions.text: All are true regarding unsaturated fats except?

choices.text: Contain one or more double bonds in their fatty acid chains.
Primarily found in plant-based sources and fish.
Increase the risk of cardiovascular disease.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Increase the risk of cardiovascular disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Unsaturated fats lower the risk of cardiovascular disease.

 

Fats, or lipids, are essential macronutrients that play crucial roles in the body, including energy storage, hormone production, and cell structure maintenance.

 

Importance:

  1. Energy Source: 9 calories per gram, more than twice the energy carbohydrates or proteins provide.
  2. Cellular Functions: Integral components of cell membranes, maintaining fluidity and integrity.
  3. Absorption of Fat-Soluble Vitamins A, D, E, and K
  4. Hormone Production: Steroid hormones such as estrogen, testosterone, and cortisol.
  5. Insulation and Protection.

 

Types of Fats

 

Saturated Fats
  • Fatty acid chains have no double bonds, making them solid at room temperature.
  • Predominantly found in animal products such as meat, dairy, and eggs, as well as some plant-based oils like coconut oil and palm oil.
  • Consuming high amounts is associated with increasing levels of LDL cholesterol (bad cholesterol) in the blood, which can raise the risk of cardiovascular diseases such as heart disease and stroke.

Unsaturated Fats
  • Contain one or more double bonds in their fatty acid chains, which makes them usually liquid at room temperature. (Option A and B)
  • Primarily found in plant-based sources such as oils, nuts, and seeds, as well as in fish. (Option C)
  • Considered healthier for consumption as they Improve blood cholesterol levels, reduce inflammation, and lower the risk of cardiovascular disease. (Option D)
  • Types:
    • Monounsaturated fats: single, double bond.
    • Polyunsaturated fats: Multiple double bonds; includes Omega-3 and Omega-6

Trans Fats
  • Industrially produced fats are found in partially hydrogenated oils.

questions.text: A patient with a history of cardiovascular disease is advised by their doctor to incorporate oils rich in polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) into their diet, with a recommendation of oils containing more than 50% PUFA. Which of the following oils would not be recommended?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Coconut Oil

Explanation:

Coconut oil is primarily composed of saturated fats, with very low levels of polyunsaturated fats. It contains approximately 6% PUFA, significantly lower than oils like safflower, sunflower, and soybean oils, which contain more than 50% PUFA.

Due to its high saturated fat content, coconut oil raises LDL cholesterol levels and potentially increases the risk of cardiovascular disease.

Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA):

  • They are dietary fats characterised by having more than one double bond.
  • Types: omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids.
  • Role in cardiovascular health:
    • Lowers levels of triglycerides (a type of fat in the blood).
    • Reduce LDL cholesterol, thereby improving the lipid profile and reducing the risk of atherosclerosis and cardiovascular disease.

 

Oils rich in PUFA, such as safflower (Option A), sunflower(Option B), and soybean oils(Option C), are recommended for heart health because they improve blood cholesterol levels and reduce the risk of cardiovascular events when consumed in moderation.

questions.text: A patient presents with rough, dry, scaly skin patches on their elbows, knees, buttocks, and hair follicle keratosis (bumps around hair follicles). Which nutrient deficiency is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Phrynoderma is a manifestation of nutritional deficiency involving Vitamin A, E or essential fatty acids (EFA), particularly linoleic acid (an omega-6 fatty acid) and alpha-linolenic acid (an omega-3 fatty acid).

These fatty acids are crucial for maintaining the integrity and function of the skin barrier. A deficiency can lead to dry, scaly skin.

 

Characterised by the presence of small, rough, cone-shaped papules (follicular hyperkeratosis) on the skin, typically on the outer surface of the upper arms, thighs, buttocks, and sometimes on the face. Can be asymptomatic or associated with mild itching.

Treatment

  • Intake of foods rich in omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids, such as fish, nuts, seeds, and vegetable oils.
  • Treating any underlying conditions contributing to malabsorption or dietary restrictions.
  • Emollients and moisturizers.

questions.text:
Which statements regarding partially hydrogenated vegetable oils are correct?

1. Longer shelf life compared to unprocessed oils.

2. Fortified with Vitamin A

3. Liquid at room temperature

4. Contains Trans fats

5. No association with increased risk of heart disease.

6. Primarily used in cooking oils to enhance flavor.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) 1, 2, and 4

Explanation:

  • Partially hydrogenated vegetable oils are created through a chemical process called Hydrogenation.
  • Fortified with Vitamin A and D.(Statement 2)
    • Eg. Vanaspati ghee/ dalda ghee.
  • Purpose of Hydrogenation:
    • Solidification of oil to fat ( Solid at room temperature).(Statement 3)
    • Increase Shelf Life, Easy storage & Handling/transport. (Statement 1)
  • No role in adding flavor. (Statement 6)
  • Leads to formation of Trans fats which are unsaturated fats with a different molecular structure than naturally occurring cis fats found in foods like dairy and meat. These trans fats have been linked to adverse health effects.(Statement 4)

 

Health Implications:

  • Raise levels of LDL and decrease levels of HDL which increases the risk of heart disease.(Statement 5)
  • Consumption of trans fats has been associated with insulin resistance, and a higher risk of type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: A patient is newly diagnosed with diabetes mellitus. Which of the following dietary recommendations would you recommend?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Oats

Explanation:

The glycemic index (GI) categorises foods based on how quickly they raise blood sugar levels after consumption compared to pure glucose (GI of 100).

  • A scale from 0 to 100 categorises foods into low, medium, or high based on their effect on blood glucose levels.
  • GI measures how quickly carbohydrates in food are converted into glucose and absorbed into the bloodstream.

 

Scale:

  • Low GI (≤ 55): Foods that cause a slow and gradual rise in blood glucose levels.
  • Medium GI (56-69): Foods that cause a moderate rise in blood glucose levels.
  • High GI (≥ 70): Foods that cause a rapid and significant rise in blood glucose levels.

 

Low GI (≤ 55)

Medium GI (56-69)

High GI (≥ 70)
  • Oats
  • Apples
  • Oranges
  • Lentils
  • Chickpeas
  • Kidney beans
  • Barley
  • Nuts and seeds
  • Sweet potatoes
  • Brown rice
  • Pineapple
  • Mango
  • Watermelon
  • Dairy products
  • White bread
  • Bagels
  • White rice
  • Sugary cereals
  • Potato chips
  • Dates
  • Mashed potatoes

 

Importance:

  • Blood Sugar Control: Helps in managing blood sugar levels (individuals with diabetes or insulin resistance).
  • Weight Management: Low GI diets may aid in weight management by promoting satiety and reducing hunger levels.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about dietary fiber are true?


	Promotes satiety but has no role in reducing blood glucose
	Acts as bile acid sequestrants in the small intestine
	The recommended daily intake is approximately 60 grams
	Excessive fibre intake can lead to micronutrient malabsorption
	Bowel irritation can only occur if the daily intake reaches 80 grams
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 2 and 4

 

Explanation:

 

  • Dietary fibre acts as bile acid sequestrants in the small intestine, helping to reduce blood cholesterol levels (statement 2).
  • Key actions: promotes satiety (statement 1), improves digestion, enhances gut microbiome.
  • Fibres, especially gum and pectin, also significantly reduce blood glucose levels (statement 1).
  • Recommended daily intake is approximately 30 grams (statement 3) since excessive fibre intake, especially when nearing 60 grams per day, can lead to micronutrient malabsorption (vitamins, calcium, magnesium, zinc) (statement 4).
  • Bowel irritation can also occur when 60 grams of fibre are consumed daily (statement 5).
